data.title: The Derek Fisherman's Club: NBA players-turned-Mr. Steal Your Girl
data.meta_description: Derek Fisher isn't the first NBA personality to mess with another player's significant other and get burned.
data.text:
A little advice for all the players and coaches in Toronto for NBA All-Star Weekend: Don’t do anything Derek Fisher would do.

In a world of habitual line-stepping, Fisher reportedly stepped over a clear, obvious one, and not only does it seem to have cost him his Knicks job — at least that’s part of the reason — he’s going to have a problem getting another head-coaching gig.

PHOTOS: NBA wives and girlfriends | All-time greatest Knicks

Getting romantically involved with the significant others of teammates, former teammates or — so it’s been said — the players he’s coaching? That will leave a mark on your reputation. And true or not, provable beyond a reasonable doubt or not, that’s a label that’s hard to shake.

Teams, friendships, locker rooms and, it appears, entire careers have been wrecked for such violations.

It’s hardly restricted to the NBA, of course. It’s pretty much gone on since the beginning of sports. And considering how, well, popular pro athletes are with women, why players turn away from the vast opportunities available in women who aren’t committed to teammates never has made sense, and never will.

Making even less sense is that Fisher, or anybody, hasn’t learned any lessons from the past. For example:
